results.summary: A man whose mental health was the subject of warnings is detained for killing schoolgirl Christina Edkins in a random attack on a bus in Birmingham.
results.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/636da2d3-7de3-444d-9d90-f6bbb1a7ac22"><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="70245570">    <caption>A passenger describes how she tried to help Christina, giving her CPR</caption>  </video><paragraph role="introduction">A man who killed 16-year-old Christina Edkins on a rush-hour bus in Birmingham has been detained indefinitely under the Mental Health Act.</paragraph><paragraph>Phillip Simelane, from Walsall, stabbed the teenager in a random attack as she made her way to school in March.</paragraph><paragraph>He had been released from prison, unsupervised, three months before the attack - despite warning signs over the state of his mental health.</paragraph><paragraph>The 23-year-old admitted manslaughter in a hearing at Birmingham Crown Court.</paragraph><paragraph>Mrs Justice Thirlwell, sentencing Simelane, said it was "likely to be a life-long order".</paragraph><paragraph>The judge added: "It is made for the nature of the offence and necessary to protect the public from serious harm." </paragraph><paragraph>She also expressed concern that Simelane had not been receiving treatment at the time of the killing.</paragraph><image id="70233108"/><paragraph>Christina had been travelling to Leasowes High School in Halesowen on the number 9 bus, two weeks after her 16th birthday, when she was attacked. </paragraph><quoteBox><quote><quoteText>The authorities didn't help him... just abandoned him</quoteText><quoteSource title="Christina's great uncle">Chris Melia</quoteSource></quote></quoteBox><paragraph>Simelane, who was sitting behind her on the upper deck, stabbed her in the chest as he walked past to get off.</paragraph><paragraph>He was arrested a few hours after the attack following an extensive manhunt.</paragraph><paragraph>Simelane had previously been in prison for <!-- CPS Asset ID: 24371339 --><link><caption>threatening his own mother</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-birmingham-24358472"/></link> with a knife. West Midlands Police said they had been called to his mother's address in Walsall about 20 times. </paragraph><paragraph>Seven days after completing a 101-day prison term for the threats, he was convicted for interfering with a vehicle and possessing cocaine. He was released from jail on 13 December.</paragraph><paragraph>But, according to the police, because the crimes were deemed minor offences there was no policy to monitor Simelane after he left jail.</paragraph><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="70236820">    <caption>Simelane was on the bus for more than two-and-a-half hours</caption>  </video><paragraph>During his time in prison, concerns were raised about his mental health and notes were put on his police file for suicide and self-harming risk, as well as for violence and weapons use.</paragraph><paragraph>Birmingham and Solihull Mental Health NHS Foundation Trust provided psychiatric assessments for Simelane during his prison term.</paragraph><pullOut title="Phillip Simelane" size="wide">  <list type="unordered">    <listItem>He was jailed last year for threatening his mother and had another conviction for violence</listItem>    <listItem>West Midlands Police said it had "no further contact" with Simelane between him leaving jail in December and the killing</listItem>    <listItem>Police said he was not under "any kind of care plan" after leaving prison</listItem>    <listItem>Simelane was homeless and unemployed at the time of the killing</listItem>    <listItem>He has "only recently" been diagnosed with schizophrenia, police said</listItem>    <listItem>Agencies involved in managing him before the attack are now undergoing independent reviews</listItem>  </list><paragraph role="link-promotion"><!-- CPS Asset ID: 24375121 --><link><caption>Girl's killer threatened own mother</caption><url platform="highweb" href="24358472 - Girl's killer threatened own mother"/></link></paragraph></pullOut><paragraph>It said it was conducting an external review, commissioned by Birmingham Cross City Clinical Commissioning Group, on behalf of all agencies involved in treating him.</paragraph><paragraph>In a statement, the trust promised a "thorough investigation", adding "we will seek to learn from and fully implement these findings across the healthcare providers involved".</paragraph><paragraph>Supt Richard Baker, who led the initial police investigation, said police and prison services were also carrying out reviews to determine what, if anything, could have been done to prevent Christina's death.</paragraph><paragraph>He said: "It was immediately apparent that Simelane suffered from mental health issues, and to this day we have not been able to interview him about what happened that day."</paragraph><paragraph>In court, Simelane entered his plea in front of more than 30 of Christina's friends and family, many wearing purple ribbons - Christina's favourite colour.</paragraph><crosshead>Killer 'abandoned'</crosshead><paragraph>Speaking afterwards, Christina's great uncle Chris Melia said: "We have no sense of vengeance or revenge. We just want him out of the way and [to] remember Christina.</paragraph><paragraph>"The authorities didn't help him, [they] just let him out of the prison door and let him go, just abandoned him.</paragraph><paragraph>"If there had been some help and authority he wouldn't have been on the bus."</paragraph><image id="70241816"/><paragraph>Prosecutor Peter Grieves-Smith said CCTV captured Simelane carrying a white plastic bag containing what prosecutors said was a knife, 10in to 12in in length.</paragraph><paragraph>He said within seconds of Christina boarding the bus "the defendant got up and moved forwards three seats and pulled out the knife, which he then hid".</paragraph><paragraph>Simelane then walked towards where Christina was sitting, "leant closer to her", stabbed her and started to walk off, the court heard.</paragraph><paragraph>"Such was the nature of the attack, nobody else on the upper deck realised what had happened until Christina reacted," Mr Grieves-Smith said.</paragraph><crosshead>Friends lay flowers</crosshead><paragraph>Other passengers on the bus tried to treat and comfort Christina before paramedics arrived within minutes.</paragraph><paragraph>She was stabbed at about 07:30 and was confirmed dead about 30 minutes later.</paragraph><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="70239883">    <caption>Head teacher Neil Shaw: "Christina was a hardworking girl, really driven...bright and lively"</caption>  </video><paragraph>Following her death, friends gathered by Hagley Road in Birmingham to lay flowers in Christina's memory, while many more were left outside her school's gates.</paragraph><paragraph>A memorial garden dedicated to Christina is due to be opened at her former school on Thursday.</paragraph><paragraph>Speaking on behalf of the family, the great uncle said Christina was a "bright, beautiful girl" who was looking forward to her school prom and loved sports. </paragraph><paragraph>He added: "Her headmaster said, 'if a school could choose its pupils it would be full of Christinas'.</paragraph><paragraph>"Now the family asks the question - when this man was discharged from prison on 13 December 2012, why was the recommendation, made a few weeks earlier by mental health experts, that he be supervised after release whilst adjusting to life back in the community, not followed up?"</paragraph></body>
results.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/636da2d3-7de3-444d-9d90-f6bbb1a7ac22"><paragraph>A man who killed 16-year-old Christina Edkins on a rush-hour bus in Birmingham has been detained indefinitely under the Mental Health Act.</paragraph><paragraph>Phillip Simelane, from Walsall, stabbed the teenager in a random attack as she made her way to school in March.</paragraph><paragraph>He had been released from prison, unsupervised, three months before the attack - despite warning signs over the state of his mental health.</paragraph><paragraph>The 23-year-old admitted manslaughter in a hearing at Birmingham Crown Court.</paragraph></shortFormBody>

items.summary: A man who stabbed a girl to death on a Birmingham bus had previously been jailed for threatening his own mother with a knife.
items.headline: Christina Edkins' killer Phillip Simelane threatened own mother

items.summary: A 23-year-old man has admitted stabbing a teenage girl to death as she travelled to school on a bus in Birmingham in March.

70245570.caption: A passenger describes how she tried to help Christina, giving her CPR

items.headline: Christina Edkins killing: Man detained for bus stabbing
items.shortHeadline: Man detained for random bus killing

items.summary: The head teacher at the school that Christina Edkins attended has said that her death "rocked the whole community".

70239883.caption: Head teacher Neil Shaw: "Christina was a hardworking girl, really driven...bright and lively"

items.headline: Christina Edkins killing: Head teacher on 'shocking event'
items.shortHeadline: Head teacher's shock at bus killing

items.summary: The mother of a teenager killed in a stabbing in Birmingham calls for more action to combat knife crime, on the day a man admits the manslaughter of another teenager in the city.
items.headline: Christina Edkins: Mother of Kyle Sheehan calls for knife crime action
items.shortHeadline: Mother calls for knife crime action

items.summary: How children traumatised by the murder of a 16-year-old stabbed on a bus were helped by channelling their memories into producing a magazine.
items.headline: Christina Edkins: How pupils were helped to deal with her murder

items.summary: A primary school is fundraising for a memorial award in honour of a 16-year-old girl who was fatally stabbed on a bus in Birmingham.
items.headline: Bus stab victim Christina Edkins honoured in sport award
items.shortHeadline: School honour for bus stabbing girl

items.summary: The community is still in shock following the fatal stabbing of schoolgirl Christina Edkins on a Birmingham bus, a vicar says.
items.headline: Christina Edkins stabbing: Community 'still in shock'

items.summary: Tributes are paid to a 16-year-old schoolgirl who was stabbed to death on a bus in Birmingham.
